sci:arg.name: myparameter
sci:arg.sci:help: A query string passed from the text box.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: __PoolID
sci:arg.sci:help:
__PoolID is a case insensitive string that can optionally be set to optimize the speed of execution for quick running protocols. Multiple protocols with the same value for __PoolID can share expensive resources such as database connections, Java VMs, memory, etc. reducing the execution time by 1 to 2 seconds per run. This can give a large speed improvement to protocols that run in a few seconds such as web applications and interactive reports. Longer running protocols will not see much benefit. Generally, it is a good idea to use the same __PoolID for all protocols within a single application such as an interactive report since many of the components, databases, and data structures will be similar.

__PoolID can also be specified by the client when the protocol is launched. If __PoolID is specified both as a parameter by the client and as a parameter stored within the protocol, the client's value overrides the stored value.

sci:arg.name: Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: The Run On Grid parameter tells the server to run the protocol on the grid engine if SES is configured to run with grid integration.

sci:arg.name: Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The Queue Name allows you to specify the name of the queue on the grid engine to submit the job to. Leave blank to specify the default queue.

sci:arg.name: Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Grid Options allows you to specify options to the grid engine submit command. Leave blank to specify the default options.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Reporting
sci:arg.sci:help: This group contains parameters specific to protocols containing Reporting components.

sci:arg.name: Reporting Stylesheet
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the name of a Stylesheet to be used by this protocol if any of the Reporting components have a Style selected in the Format and Position parameters.

sci:arg.name: WebExports
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties which will be automatically exported if this protocol is published as a web service.

Each global property in the list is created with an empty value at the start of the protocol run.

sci:arg.name: Keep Alive
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies if the process where this protocol is run should stay around for later use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Return a list of compound IDs as a JSON to show in the typeahead search box.

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Protocols\Examples\Semantic UI\Form\Auto-suggest in a Text Box\Fetch a Compound ID List

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Records passing out of any unconnected pass ports of components inside the subprotocol
Records passing out of any unconnected fail ports of components inside the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolModified
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Modified

sci:arg.name: OriginalComponentGUID
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalComponentGUID

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The file or URL source to read

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.
  • Process Complex Data Header Lines: Data header lines are the lines in the SD format that precede the actual data. They can contain the data field name (enclosed in angular brackets <>), the data field number (as DTn), the external registry number (enclosed in parentheses), and other optional information. When this parameter is set to False, only the data field name is parsed and used to set the corresponding property name. All the other information in the line is ignored. When the parameter is set to true, all the information is parsed. The property name is set from either the field name in <> or the DTn. If both are present the field name takes priority and the DTn number is saved as an additional property named FieldName#DTn. The external registry number is saved as FieldName#ExtRegNum and any other information is saved as FieldName#OtherDataFieldInfo. When the molecules are written to an SD file, the data header lines are reconstructed from these properties. The default state of this parameter is False, as parsing, preserving, and eventually writing all the information in the data header lines can be costly, specially for SD files with many data fields.
  • Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types: 'H2' and 'H+' are two non-standard element types that can be assigned to atoms by the Accelrys Draw sketcher. They represent unattached Hydrogen (a Hydrogen molecule) and charged Hydrogen (a proton), respectively. When this parameter is selected, these atom types are converted to standard hydrogen atoms upon reading, with charges of 0 for H2 and +1 for H+. Otherwise, these atoms are read and perceived as unknown atom types, with 'H2' and 'H+' as the atom labels.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types

sci:arg.name: ReadProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: Select True to read the properties for each molecule (in addition to the structures)

sci:arg.name: ReadQueryInfo
sci:arg.sci:help: If properties starting with "QueryInfo" are present, use them to set up query information on the atoms and bonds. (This is how, for example, SMARTS query information can be preserved when writing to an SD format file.) This information only contains information that cannot be written out in MOL/SD format.

sci:arg.name: PutNameInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the name of each molecule

sci:arg.name: PutCommentInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the comment associated with each molecule

sci:arg.name: Global Templates
sci:arg.sci:help:
V3000 SD or MOL files containing template definitions for amino acid, nucleic acid or other residues or monomers. These templates can then be refered to by molecules read by the SD reader.

The default template file included in the Chemistry collection, data\Direct\Direct_templates.mol contains definitions for 22 amino acids and 8 DNA and RNA templates.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Loads 137,000 compounds from the Asinex vendor catalog

Reads molecules and property data from a zipped SD file containing approximately 137,000 compounds from Asinex.

See Also:

  • This is a specific instance of the SD Reader.
Data fields in the SD file will be added to the property fields

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: The PilotScript expression used to filter the data.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
An expression evaluated only when the component is first initialized (when the first data record enters).

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
An expression evaluated only when the component is finalized (once the last data record has passed).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Allows any properties that were calculated in "Expression" to be included with the exiting record. Otherwise, these properties are removed after the evaluation is complete.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "Expression" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Passes data records for which a PilotScript expression evaluates to True

For each incoming data record, the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated. If the last statement in the expression evaluates to True or non-zero, the record is sent out the Pass port. Otherwise it is sent out the Fail port.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to True or non-zero
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to False or zero

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Passes data records for which a PilotScript expression evaluates to True

For each incoming data record, the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated. If the last statement in the expression evaluates to True or non-zero, the record is sent out the Pass port. Otherwise it is sent out the Fail port.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to True or non-zero
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to False or zero

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: List
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of which data records to pass: e.g., 1,3-5,7,10-11 will pass the first, third, fourth, fifth and so on.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "List" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Passes data records within a specified range based on the order in which they arrive

Data records are numbered consecutively (from 1) as they arrive at the component. The record numbers specified by List are sent out the Pass port. Records not specified are sent out the Fail port.

List items need to be entered as comma-separated values. List can accept single item indices or ranges (such as "1-5,7,9,13-15").
Data records whose indices match the specified list
Data records whose indices do not match the specified list

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.
  • Process Complex Data Header Lines: Data header lines are the lines in the SD format that precede the actual data. They can contain the data field name (enclosed in angular brackets <>), the data field number (as DTn), the external registry number (enclosed in parentheses), and other optional information. When this parameter is set to False, only the data field name is parsed and used to set the corresponding property name. All the other information in the line is ignored. When the parameter is set to true, all the information is parsed. The property name is set from either the field name in <> or the DTn. If both are present the field name takes priority and the DTn number is saved as an additional property named FieldName#DTn. The external registry number is saved as FieldName#ExtRegNum and any other information is saved as FieldName#OtherDataFieldInfo. When the molecules are written to an SD file, the data header lines are reconstructed from these properties. The default state of this parameter is False, as parsing, preserving, and eventually writing all the information in the data header lines can be costly, specially for SD files with many data fields.
  • Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types: 'H2' and 'H+' are two non-standard element types that can be assigned to atoms by the Accelrys Draw sketcher. They represent unattached Hydrogen (a Hydrogen molecule) and charged Hydrogen (a proton), respectively. When this parameter is selected, these atom types are converted to standard hydrogen atoms upon reading, with charges of 0 for H2 and +1 for H+. Otherwise, these atoms are read and perceived as unknown atom types, with 'H2' and 'H+' as the atom labels.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types

sci:arg.name: ReadProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: Select True to read the properties for each molecule (in addition to the structures)

sci:arg.name: ReadQueryInfo
sci:arg.sci:help: If properties starting with "QueryInfo" are present, use them to set up query information on the atoms and bonds. (This is how, for example, SMARTS query information can be preserved when writing to an SD format file.) This information only contains information that cannot be written out in MOL/SD format.

sci:arg.name: PutNameInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the name of each molecule

sci:arg.name: PutCommentInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the comment associated with each molecule

sci:arg.name: Global Templates
sci:arg.sci:help:
V3000 SD or MOL files containing template definitions for amino acid, nucleic acid or other residues or monomers. These templates can then be refered to by molecules read by the SD reader.

The default template file included in the Chemistry collection, data\Direct\Direct_templates.mol contains definitions for 22 amino acids and 8 DNA and RNA templates.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Loads 137,000 compounds from the Asinex vendor catalog

Reads molecules and property data from a zipped SD file containing approximately 137,000 compounds from Asinex.

See Also:

  • This is a specific instance of the SD Reader.
Data fields in the SD file will be added to the property fields

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Action
sci:arg.sci:help: Options for the type of standardization you can perform. The default is to standardize the charging and stereochemistry of the molecule. If multiple actions are selected, they are performed in the given order.
sci:arg.sci:member: Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction

sci:arg.name: Acids
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for single-bonded Oxygen atoms in carboxylic, sulfuric and phosphoric acid groups.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.

sci:arg.name: Single Halogen Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for any unconnected halogen atom found in the molecule.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.

sci:arg.name: Single Metal Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether to charge, uncharge or keep the current charge for any unconnected metal atom found in the molecule.
This option is enabled only when "StandardizeCharges" is selected in the Action parameter.

sci:arg.name: Normalize Metals in Group 1A
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, a covalent bond is defined between positively charged ions in Group 1A (Li+, Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+) and corresponding counter ions (C-, N-, Si-, P-). Also, covalent bonds between neutral Group 1A elements and neutral halogens or Oxygen are converted into ionic species, breaking the bond and charging the previously attached atoms to create (Li+, Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+) and (X-, O-).

sci:arg.name: Mark Unknown Stereo Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: When standardizing stereo, look for true stereo centers missing stereo marks (wedge bonds) and mark them as Unknown Stereo atoms, with their corresponding 'wiggly' bonds.

sci:arg.name: Process Pseudo Stereo Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to include pseudo stereo atoms not marked with up or down bond wedges (unknown pseudo stereo) when doing "StandardizeStereo" or "SetStereoFromCoordinates".

sci:arg.name: Preserve Stereo Marks On
sci:arg.sci:help:
Allow wedge bonds on certain atoms with perceived SP2 hybridization:
  • Allenes: Carbon atoms at the end of allene groups.
  • Restricted Biphenyls:Atoms at the ortho positions of geometrically restricted biphenyl or biaryl rings.
  • Conjugated SP2 Nitrogens:Nitrogen atoms with three single bonds which are perceived to be SP2 because of conjugation with neighboring groups.
  • Uncharged Tetrahedral Nitrogens: Normally Pipeline Pilot only recognizes Nitrogen as a tetrahedral stereocenter when it has a positive charge and four heavy attachments. Selecting this parameter will bypass this restriction and mark other Nitrogen stereocenters (such as Nitrogen atoms with three single bonds) as bad only if they fail the check of ambiguous wedge-bond geometry.

sci:arg.name: Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction
sci:arg.sci:help: This parameter controls whether or not to invert the bond stereo (up or down) when changing the direction of the wedge bond by selecting "FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds" in the Action parameter.

sci:arg.name: Remove Explicit Valences
sci:arg.sci:help: Remove explicit valence values from atoms when clearing query infomation

sci:arg.name: Track Actions Taken
sci:arg.sci:help: When enabled, this will keep track of which actions resulted in changes to the input molecule. Actions that result in changes will be listed in a property called Standardize_Actions_Taken.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Standardize Ionizable Groups
sci:arg.sci:help: Transform ionizable groups such as sulphates, phosphates and guanidiniums to a standard form.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies selected predefined actions to input molecules such as standardizing charges or stereo, or the clearing of various attributes

One or more actions can be applied to each molecule to standardize the way molecules are presented to downstream components.

Standardization is important when comparing molecular libraries from different sources. If different rules were used for structural representation when creating these libraries, a straight comparison would yield incorrect results. The options below allow you to apply a consistent set of rules to structures before comparing them.

Available actions:

  • StandardizeStereo: Atoms that are perceived as true stereo atoms but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownAtomStereo, EvenAtomStereo, or OddAtomStereo) are set to UnknownAtomStereo. Atoms that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereoatoms are set to NoAtomStereo. 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
    Similarly, bonds that are perceived as true stereo double bonds, but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownBondStereo, CisBondStereo, or TransBondStereo) are set to UnknownBondStereo. Bonds that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereo bonds are set to NoBondStereo. Again, 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
  • StandardizeCharges: Sets standard formal charges for common functional groups: Quaternary Nitrogen: +1
    Nitro groups: N+(=O)O-
    Diazonium N: +1
    Oxygen with three attachments: +1
    X=O-C Oxygen: +1
    Sulfur with three attachments: +1
    S=O-C Sulfur: +1
    F, Cl, Br, I with no attachments: -1
    Note that halogen acids with explicit hydrogens (H-X) are not modified.
  • CenterMolecule: Translates the molecule to the center of geometry.
  • RemoveSingleAtomFragments: Removes all unattached atoms from the molecule.
  • KeepSmallestFragment: Keeps only the fragment with fewer atoms in the case of multifragment molecules.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[C]Atoms: Converts all the atoms in the molecule to Carbon.
  • MakeNon[C,H]Atoms[Q]Atoms: Converts all non-carbon, non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the Q query atom type.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[A]Atoms: Converts all non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the A query atom type.
  • MakeAllBondsSingle: Converts all the bonds in the molecule to Single bonds.
  • ClearCoordinates: Sets all x, y, z coordinates to zero.
  • FixCoordinateDimension: Checks the x, y, z atomic coordinates and sets the dimension for the molecule accordingly:
    • 3 if non-zero values are found for x or y, and for z.
    • 2 if non-zero values are found for x or y, but not for z.
    • 0 if all x, y, z coordinates are zero.
  • StraightenTripleBonds: Looks for triple bonds with non-linear geometry and makes them linear. In some cases this action could cause atoms to overlap each other. This can be checked with the Bump Check Filter and the bumps resolved using the 'Resolve Bumps Only' option in 2D Coords.
  • StraightenAllenes: Looks for allene structures with non-linear geometry and makes them linear. In some cases this action could cause atoms to overlap each other. This can be checked with the Bump Check Filter and the bumps resolved using the 'Resolve Bumps Only' option in 2D Coords.
  • ClearMolecule: Deletes all atoms and bonds in the molecule, keeping the molecule object in the data record.
  • RemoveMolecule: Deletes the molecule object from the data record.
  • ClearStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds to NoStereo.
  • ClearEnhancedStereo: Clears all relative atom stereo groups (enhanced stereo) from the molecule.
  • ClearUnknownStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownAtomStereo: Sets all atoms that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownCisTransBondStereo: Sets all bonds that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearCisTransBondStereo: Sets all bonds that are marked CisStereo or TransStereo to UnknownStereo.
  • ClearCharges: Sets all formal charges to zero.
  • SetStereoFromCoordinates: This option uses the 2D coordinates and up/down bond markings, or the 3D coordinates, to assign the stereochemistry of the atoms or bonds. Typically, this is done by the readers or the molecules from text components. Occasionally, components may create molecules that need to have their stereo reperceived.
  • RepositionStereoBonds: This option repositions the stereo bond markings, trying to find the best bond to mark as a wedge bond for each stereo atom.
  • RepositionAxialStereoBonds: This option repositions the stereo bond markings on axial stereo centers (allenes and atropisomers). This is more expensive than the tetrahedral reposition action as it requires perceiving rings and aromaticity.
  • FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds: This option checks the wedge bonds in the molecule to make sure that the wedge is drawn with the stereo atom at the narrow end of the wedge. Any wedge bond for which there is a stereo atom at the wide end and no stereo atom at the narrow end is reversed to point in the other direction. A separate option, Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction, controls whether or not to invert the bond stereo (up or down) when changing the direction of the wedge bond.
  • ClearQueryInfo: Deletes all query information from atoms and bonds.
  • ClearHighlightColors: Clears any highlight colors from atoms and bonds.
  • ClearAtomLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the atoms.
  • ClearBondLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the bonds.
  • NeutralizeBondedZwitterions: Converts directly bonded zwitterions (positively charged atom bonded to negatively charged atom, A+B-) to the neutral representation (A=B)
  • ClearUnusualValence: Clears any atom valence query features and resets all implicit hydrogen counts to their standard values.
  • ClearIsotopes: Clears any isotope information from the atoms in the molecule, setting all to the most common isotopes.
  • ClearDativeBonds: Clears explicit dative bonds (as found in V3000 mol files).
  • ClearHydrogenBonds: Clears explicit hydrogen bonds (as found in V3000 mol files).
  • LocalizeMarkushRAtomsOnRings: Takes molecules with delocalized R atoms (R atoms pointing to center of the ring) and replaces them with R atoms attached to all available positions in the ring.

Note:

  • To remove sgroups or invalidate their coordinates, use Clear Sgroup Features

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Merge Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: Options controlling the details of how properties are merged together

sci:arg.name: WhenMerging
sci:arg.sci:help:
Provides fine control over how multiple values are treated when merging data records together.

  • OverwriteOrCreate: Copies all properties of each merged record sequentially, overwriting any values that may already exist (instead of generating an array).
  • OverwriteExisting: Only copies properties that already exist on the first merged record, overwriting those original values (instead of creating an array).
  • CreateIfNew: Leaves any existing properties alone, and writes only new properties.
  • AppendOrCreate: Appends (as an array) if a property already exists, otherwise creates it.
  • AppendExisting: Appends (as an array) only to currently existing properties, and discards other new property values.

sci:arg.name: KeepAllNullString
sci:arg.sci:help: This string is used during append to pad out empty values. It keeps the number of values of generated arrays of values the same, and in sync, for multiple samples. The default value is None, which causes no padding to occur.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: KeepAllPreferredNodeName
sci:arg.sci:help: If defined, this contains a name that is used to prioritize which underlying data record should be kept. If not defined, the first data record is kept; if this is defined, and at least one of the data records contains a node of this type, then the first example of that type is kept.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll'); Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: PrefixUsingProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: When multiple values for a property are retained, the original property name is prefixed differently for each original value it must hold. The prefix is constructed from the value of this property, followed by an underscore. When not specified, a prefix is not used and multiple values are separated as an array (such as property[1], property[2], etc).

sci:arg.name: OutputFrequency
sci:arg.sci:help: Add a property called "Frequency" that contains the number of individual data records included in the resulting merged record. This value is simply the total number of input records.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: MergeBehavior
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

  • KeepAll: Keeps all property values by appending values into an array.
  • KeepFirst: Keeps only the properties and values from the first example received. All properties and values from subsequent records matching the property specified by MergeUsing are discarded.

sci:arg.name: MergeUsing
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the property (or a comma-separated list of properties) that will be used to merge on. Data records having the same value for this property will be merged. This property must contain scalar (i.e., non-array) data.

If multiple properties are specified, the values must be the same for all of the properties (unless MergeUsingListType is set to UseFirstDefinedValue).

sci:arg.name: MergeUsingListType
sci:arg.sci:help:
How MergeUsing properties are interpreted when more than one property is listed:

  • UseFirstDefinedValue: Use only the first property in the list that has a defined value for a record as the merge key.
  • UseAllValues: Use the concatentation of values of all properties listed as the merge key.

sci:arg.name: MergePropertyType
sci:arg.sci:help:
The types of values found in the property specified by MergeUsing:

  • IsNumeric: All numbers are converted to doubles for comparison (e.g., 1 = 1.0).
  • IsText: All comparisons are made as string values.
  • IsDate: The key is considered a date.
  • IsFingerprint: The key is considered a fingerprint. Fingerprint bits are sorted before making the comparison.

sci:arg.name: IgnoreCase
sci:arg.sci:help: Considers lower-case and upper-case letters as equivalent when determining the identity of MergeUsing property values.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergePropertyType to IsText'); Parameter('MergePropertyType') eq 'IsText'

sci:arg.name: AcceptNonNumericStringsAsNumbers
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines whether all string values for the MergeUsing property -- even non-numeric ones such as 'abc' or '1.0c' -- will be coerced to numbers when MergePropertyType is set to IsNumeric. If set to True, then a string such as 'abc' that does not begin with a numeric portion will be coerced to zero, while a string such as '1.0c' that begins with a numeric portion will be coerced to the corresponding number (in this case 1.0). If set to False, then records containing non-numeric strings for the MergeUsing property will be sent out the Fail port.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Merges properties of all input data records into a single output data record

Performs faster than Merge Data for the special case where all input records are to be merged into one. MergeBehavior controls how properties are handled.

See Also:

  • If you wish to merge data records that share identical values of a specified property, use Merge Data.
A single data record containing all merged properties of the input records

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ReplaceNullsInFirstRecord
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether to replace nulls in the first merged record when KeepAllNullString is specified.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Merge All
sci:arg.sci:help: Internal parameter indicating that all data records are to be merged into one, irrespective of the value of the MergeUsing Property.

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Data Access and Manipulation\Manipulators\Merge All Data

sci:arg.name: Property Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The property name for the destination data.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters.

sci:arg.name: Output All Nodes
sci:arg.sci:help: If true, this component will recurse down the node tree, creating the corresponding objects in the JSON output based on the node names.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: If Destination Exists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the destination property already exists

sci:arg.name: Destination
sci:arg.sci:help: The property name for the destination data.

sci:arg.name: IfFileExists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the destination file already exists

sci:arg.name: Complete
sci:arg.sci:help: When "For Each Data" is selected, data is written for each data record. Otherwise, data is written to a new data record after all input data records have been processed.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Writes input data record as JSON encoded string

For each incoming data record, this component creates a property that represents the record as an object in JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) format.

Data record properties are mapped to JSON fields. When the parameter Output All Nodes is True (default), this component will recurse down the node tree, creating the corresponding JSON objects based on the node names. Arrays and n-dimensional arrays are supported, and Pipeline Pilot data types will be mapped to JavaScript primitive types where appropriate.

With the default parameterization, the output will be of the form:

{"name1":"value1","name2":"value2"}

Note:

  • To learn more about JSON, visit the JSON.org web site.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Data Access and Manipulation\Converters\Data to JSON

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Adds any properties calculated in this component to a data record's property list.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Do Screen
sci:arg.sci:help: When TRUE, controls which exit port is used for each data record by evaluating the final expression (or only one) listed in the "Expression" parameter. -Pass (green) port when expression true -Fail (red) port when expression false

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Destination
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name or path name for the destination data. The destination can be a file, a network resource, a data record property, or a global property.
  • Use a network URL for a network resource.
  • Use a file path name for a file.
  • Use "global://property-name" for a global property.

Note:

  • When the destination is a file or network resource, be sure to specify an extension such as .txt or .doc. To save in compressed (zipped) format, add the extension .gz or .zip to the filename.

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to write (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: IfFileExists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the given destination file already exists

sci:arg.name: CharacterEncoding
sci:arg.sci:help:
Indicates the character set that will be used within the file.

ANSI is the default and specifies a character set where each character is defined by a single byte. This allows the Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) character set to be written to the file. Virtually all applications can read these files.

UTF-8 specifies a variable length character set. Each character is represented by 1 to 6 bytes. This allows writing out all extended characters specified in the Unicode character sets while maintaining reasonably lengthed files. Many applications do not support UTF-8 files.

"Unicode" and "Unicode big endian" are sets where each character is represented by exactly 2 bytes (also known as UCS-2). Depending on which is used will determine the order in which the bytes appear for each character. Many applications do not support Unicode or Unicode big endian files.

For more information about each of these encoding styles, go to http://www.unicode.org/

sci:arg.name: UseByteOrderMark
sci:arg.sci:help:
The byte order mark (BOM) is an optional Unicode character written to the start of a file or data stream that can be used to indicate the character encoding of the following data. Spefically it can be used to indicate the various UTF-8 and UTF-16 encodings.

BOMs are more widely used in a Windows setting. (For example, Windows Notepad includes a BOM in UTF-8 files.)

Setting options are:

Always
For non-ANSI encodings, the BOM is always written at the start of the output stream.
Never
No BOM is written at the start of the output stream.
Native
This is equivalent to "Always" on Windows and "Never" on Linux.

sci:arg.name: BeginningText
sci:arg.sci:help: Text that should precede each record written out.

sci:arg.name: EndingText
sci:arg.sci:help: Any text to be included after each record written out.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: PropertyNames
sci:arg.sci:help: List of properties to write (separated by commas). "*" indicates to write all properties.

sci:arg.name: IncludePropertyNames
sci:arg.sci:help: Display the name of each property along with its values

sci:arg.name: HierarchyDepth
sci:arg.sci:help: Controls the maximum depth within hierarchical data records to display node and property information. No hierarchical information will be displayed if depth is set to -1. If no value is set, the default is 0.

sci:arg.name: NewlineStyle
sci:arg.sci:help:
Set this value to define the line ending character(s) in the output file. The default value is the Windows-standard carriage return plus line feed (CR+LF), but you may need to change this, especially in a non-Windows environment. Options are:

  • CR+LF (Traditional Windows text file line ending)
  • LF (Line feed, '\n', 0x0A)
  • CR (Carriage return, '\r', 0x0D)
  • Native (CR+LF on Windows, LF on Linux)

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Writes data records to a text file

Data records are formatted as text and written to the file specified by Destination. Each property value is separated by a new line. Separation of data records can be controlled using the parameters under Delimiter Options.

Note:
  • Use HierarchyDepth to control the display of deep properties and nodes from hierarchical data records.
See Also:
  • To write a file formatted with one data record per row with delimiters between the property values, use the Delimited Text Writer.
  • To write out binary data (such as a .png file), use the Binary Writer.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:value: WARNING! This is a Pipeline Pilot protocol written in version 8.0 or later. It contains features that are not supported in earlier versions of Pipeline Pilot.
